content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <feed xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom"> <title>Hanes a Hanes Cymru / History & Welsh History</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/2160/12" rel="alternate"/> <subtitle/> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/2160/12</id> <updated>2015-03-20T04:02:59Z</updated> <dc:date>2015-03-20T04:02:59Z</dc:date> <entry> <title>John Lewis and the promotion of the international evangelical revival, 17351756</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/2160/27590" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>David</name> </author> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/2160/27590</id> <updated>2015-03-19T22:03:06Z</updated> <published>2009-01-01T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">John Lewis and the promotion of the international evangelical revival, 17351756 David Dyfed Wyn </summary> <dc:date>2009-01-01T00:00:00Z</dc:date> </entry> <entry> <title>The People's Radio? The BBC and its audience 1939-45</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/2160/27481" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Sian</name> </author> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/2160/27481</id> <updated>2015-03-16T22:04:48Z</updated> <published>1999-01-01T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">The People's Radio? The BBC and its audience 1939-45 Sian Nick; Jeff This collection of essays brings together the latest historical research on cultural production and reception during the Second World War. Its starting point is how this war was presented to, and understood by, contemporaries and how they differentiated it from earlier conflicts. Although this was particularly noticeable in the construction of ideas of inclusiveness and commonality where the people' pulled together to secure victory and a socially equitable peace, the essays also seek to explore the diversity of institutional and personal experiences. Essays look at major national institutions and industries such as the recently formed BBC, the culturally diverse and rapidly expanding commercial press, and the British film industry. The collection explores the role of the individual agent, with studies on established writers and composers, and how each related to the collective rationales of wartime. </summary> <dc:date>1999-01-01T00:00:00Z</dc:date> </entry> <entry> <title>Gareth Davies</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/2160/27482" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Sian</name> </author> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/2160/27482</id> <updated>2015-03-16T22:04:48Z</updated> <published>1999-01-01T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Gareth Davies Sian Huw; Peter; Gareth </summary> <dc:date>1999-01-01T00:00:00Z</dc:date> </entry> <entry> <title>\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdAll the news that\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds fit to broadcast\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd: The popular press versus the BBC, 1922-1945</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/2160/27480" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Sian</name> </author> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/2160/27480</id> <updated>2015-03-16T22:04:47Z</updated> <published>2000-07-14T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdAll the news that\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds fit to broadcast\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd: The popular press versus the BBC, 1922-1945 Sian Peter; Adrian; Colin </summary> <dc:date>2000-07-14T00:00:00Z</dc:date> </entry> </feed>
